facts.text: Canal after temporary closure restarted flowing on May 5, 1953.
Deceased Shivlal allowed to take water to irrigate fields although not his turn.
On May 6, canal flowing full capacity; Shivlal's turn 6 hours from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m., but watered lands 8 a.m. to 10:30 a.m. to fill village diggi.
Mirab Ram Karan PW1 with consent of Shivlal diverted water to fill diggi, promising rest of turn (3.5 hours) after.
Diggi filled by 1 p.m. on May 7; Shivlal wanted to divert water to field but Bhagwandas prevented, claiming turn his.
Turn of Bhagwandas after Surta, whose turn next after Shivlal.
Shivlal prevented from water, walked towards village to speak to Mirab; Bhagwandas shouted 'enemy going' and hit Shivlal on head with kassi.
Netram hit Shivlal with lathi; Shivlal fell; both beat him; Mt. Rameshwari joined with wooden handle of kassi.
Occurrence witnessed by Hazari PW3 grazing camels in Surta's field; he shouted, assailants left kassi and went.
Hazari found Shivlal seriously injured unconscious; sprinkled water, revived; Shivlal asked to take to Thana but walked to Khala of Hukma.
Hazari left Shivlal with Jora, Jagmal, Bhogar, Begaram, Binja; told them what seen.
Shivlal taken to Raisinghnagar by Bhaggu and Jagmal on she-camel to shop of Gyani Ram PW4.
At shop, Shivlal told Gyani Ram that Bhagwandas, Netram, Rameshwari assaulted due to water dispute; asked to send for son Ram Pratap and Artya Ishardas.
Ram Pratap arrived ~6 p.m.; Shivlal repeated story; then taken to hospital by Jagmal, Bhaggu etc.
At hospital ~5 p.m., Shivlal unconscious; treated by doctor PW11; died May 8 at 8:15 a.m.
15 injuries; No.1 sharp-edged grievous fatal, No.2 blunt grievous fatal.
FIR based on written report Ex P-1 by Ram Pratap s/o Shivlal, recorded May 7 ~7:30 p.m.
Dying declarations to Jora PW7, Gyani Ram PW4, Ram Pratap PW5.
Recovery of kassi.
Sessions Judge acquitted all accused (Bhagwandas, Netram, Mt. Rameshwari) under s.302 IPC.
High Court reversed acquittal of Bhagwandas and Netram, convicted under s.302 r/w s.34, life transportation; affirmed acquittal of Mt. Rameshwari.
Special leave under Art.136.

legal_issues.text: Whether there was sufficient evidence against appellants to warrant conviction
Whether there were compelling reasons for reversal of acquittal judgment

petitioner_arguments.text: No evidence against appellants sufficient to warrant conviction
No compelling reasons for reversal of acquittal

respondent_arguments.text: Prosecution case supported by two eyewitnesses (Begaram PW2, Hazari PW3), dying declarations to three persons, recovery of kassi

court_reasoning.text: Begaram PW2 disbelieved by both Sessions Judge and High Court
court_reasoning.key_observation: Hazari PW3 sole eyewitness; contradictions with Begaram; High Court said Begaram's presence doubtful, Hazari mentioned him because prosecution producing; detracts from reliability

court_reasoning.text: Hazari's testimony diminished by contradictions, especially innocence of Mt. Rameshwari
Dying declarations to Gyani Ram PW4 and Jora PW7 have material contradictions at various stages; Sessions Judge rejected; not sure foundation alone for murder conviction
Doctor's evidence: Shivlal unconscious at hospital 5pm; injuries suggest improbable he walked or talked for declarations; High Court erred relying on medical books without putting to doctor
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sundarlal v. State of MP disapproves such

court_reasoning.text: Recovery of kassi neutral; not proved belonged to Bhagwandas
Evidence such no tribunal could legitimately infer guilt; set aside conviction though High Court findings differ
High Court should not set aside acquittal unless substantial compelling reasons; judgment discloses none
court_reasoning.key_observation: Surajpal Singh, Ajmer Singh, Aher Raja Khima

holdings.text: Evidence insufficient for legitimate inference of guilt
No substantial and compelling reasons to reverse acquittal

precedents_cited.case_name: Sundarlal v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Disapproved judges drawing conclusions adverse to accused from medical books without putting passages to witness
No grounds on evidence for tribunal to infer guilt legitimately; set aside conviction
High Court should not set aside acquittal unless substantial compelling reasons

precedents_cited.case_name: Ajmer Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court should not set aside acquittal unless substantial compelling reasons

precedents_cited.case_name: Aher Raja Khima v. State of Saurashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court should not set aside acquittal unless substantial compelling reasons

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offence of murder with common intention

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside the conviction and sentences passed by Rajasthan High Court on Bhagwandas and Netram, restored acquittal by Sessions Judge.

key_quotes.text: "there are here no grounds on the evidence, taken as a whole, upon which any Tribunal could properly, as a matter of legitimate inference, arrive at a conclusion that the appellant was guilty"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quoting Privy Council to hold evidence insufficient for guilt inference

key_quotes.text: This Court has held that the High Court should not set aside an acquittal unless there are substantial and compelling reasons for doing so.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle for interfering with acquittal, applied to reverse High Court
